MenuItem.title: MenuItem
MenuItem.description: Represents a menu item proposed by a hostel resident.

id.description: Unique identifier for the menu item.

title.description: The name of the menu item.

ingredients.description: A comma-separated list of ingredients in the menu item.

photoUrl.description: URL of the photo of the menu item.

preparationInstructions.description: Detailed instructions on how to prepare the menu item.

nutritionalFacts.description: Nutritional information about the menu item.

isVegan.description: Indicates whether the menu item is vegan.

isVegetarian.description: Indicates whether the menu item is vegetarian.

submitterId.description: Reference to User who submitted this menu item. (Relationship: User 1:N MenuItem)

Vote.title: Vote
Vote.description: Represents a user's vote for a menu item.

menuItemId.description: Reference to the MenuItem being voted on. (Relationship: MenuItem 1:N Vote)

voterId.description: Reference to the User who cast the vote. (Relationship: User 1:N Vote)

rank.description: The rank/score assigned to the menu item by the voter.

email.description: The email address of the user.

firestore.reasoning: The Firestore structure is designed to support a hostel menu voting application with a focus on security, scalability, and ease of debugging. It leverages denormalization for authorization independence and structural segregation for simplified security rules. The core entities are `User`, `MenuItem`, and `Vote`.  User data is stored under the `/users/{userId}` path. Menu items, owned by users, are stored under `/menuItems/{menuItemId}`. This collection stores a `submitterId` to tie the `MenuItem` back to the `User`, but the security rule doesn't need to 'get()' the User document because the `submitterId` is present. Votes for each menu item are kept under `/menuItems/{menuItemId}/votes/{voteId}`. This structure enables performant `list` operations and simplifies security rule definitions.  This design enforces Authorization Independence, since the security rules for votes will rely on the `voterId` field within the `Vote` document itself to ensure that only the user who created the vote can modify/delete it. This avoids the need to `get()` the `User` document in the security rules.
